The reasoning behind the initial banning of Kratom in Thailand  may provide a clue as to the proper place of this plant in a nation in the grips of an opioid epidemic.  In  1943 the Thai government was faced with declining taxes from opium sales.  Citizens were turning to Kratom as an alternative to opium, to protect their cash flow the government banned the mitragyna speciosa plant.  As the tree grows naturally and consumption of the leaves either chewed or in tea was common the law was not strictly enforced.  Quite simply the plant was banned to increase opiate use.  Is that the intention of the DEA's plan to place kratom on the Schedule 1 of controlled substances?
     More recently a drink called 4x100 has become popular in Thailand.  It is a mix of kratom tea and codiene containing cough syrup with cola syrup to flavor it.  The 4x100 brings two issues to the discussion.  First, the effects of kratom are mild, it's not a party drug, and the sellers feel the need to "kick it up a notch" by adding an opiate drug to the natural tea.  Second, in the documented cases of fatalities related to kratom it was not the only substance used.  For instance if an individual took valium, kratom, percocet, alcohol, nicotine and cocaine and then died it isn't the kratom that killed them.
     Many people have commented on the improvement in their lives after they began using kratom.  I am one of them, the leaves help me remain active despite orthopedic problems that cause chronic pain and stiffness.  I prefer kratom leaf to prescription painkillers because it relieves the pain without the mind numbing fog and constipation that accompany the prescription drugs.  To be honest the first thing I did when I read the initial plan to list kratom on Schedule 1 was to make an appointment with my doctor to get a prescription for narcotic pain relievers, because I would no longer have the most effective tool to help maintain my quality of life.  Is that the intention of the DEA's plan to list kratom on schedule 1?
     Placing kratom on Schedule 1 of controlled substances is a mistake.  There is the possibility that mitrgyna speciosa leaves may offer a helpful alternative to those people who struggle with opiate addiction.  Pure kratom leaf is relatively benign to most people and doesn't pose a danger to public health.  Many people, myself included, find that kratom is helpful in dealing with chronic pain and greatly improves the quality of our lives.  Please, do not place mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine onto Schedule 1 of controlled substances.

Hello-
I recently became aware of Kratom via online research, but that "research" is anecdotal and not based on scientific studies. I'm writing today to ask that Kratom, and plants like it, be allowed to be scientifically studied. I strongly object to any plant being banned or made illegal if it has not been independently studied for any potential harm or benefit. To me that's not just illogical, it also goes against basic human liberty and the pursuit of happiness.
 
As a resident of Washington state I've observed the positive impact of legal recreational cannabis, and the evidence confirms what I have seen;  I believe the foundation of this success is common sense regulation that restricts access to those 21 years of age and older, and taxation that benefits communities across the state. Additionally every cannabis product is labeled to accurately quantify exactly what is being purchased, which allows people to confidently know what they're buying/using.

The anecdotal evidence about Kratom being a beneficial plant is overwhelmingly positive. And there are some cases of people that have encountered issues, but that's the exception, not the rule. I have not tried Kratom because, as opposed to Washington cannabis, it lacks verifiable labeling to quantify the origin and processing of the plant.

In closing I believe we are all better off when we strive to scientifically study and understand our natural world. No plant or substance should be placed on the Schedule 1 list without thorough government and independent study and societal consensus. Alcohol prohibition was an absolute disaster, and I'd argue the same about the DEA stance towards cannabis. I strongly encourage the DEA to not repeat past mistakes, and make better policy decisions going forward.

Thank you for taking the time to read and consider my comments.

Gregory Teaderman

This comment is in reference to Docket No. DEA-442W. 

My name is Holly Jensen and I am a 32 year old consultant for nonprofits. I strongly believe that the DEA should not put kratom on the list of schedule 1 controlled substances. I added kratom to my evening tea as a sleep aid. for approximately 6-7 consecutive months from fall of 2015 through early 2016. I experienced an improvement in my sleep and anxiety issues. I used it as a basic dietary or herbal supplement, and experienced no negative effects.

Like 60 million other Americans, I suffer from insomnia. According to my psychiatrist, my insomnia is likely connected to my social anxiety disorder and obsessive compulsive disorder. I was speaking about this with a friend who is knowledgeable about teas (such as a good old-fashioned chamomile, lavender, and valerian tea to relax). She suggested I look into kratom, specifically the red vein varieties, which have been used naturally for centuries for their calming effects. 

I attempted to find and try the most natural form of kratom I could find. I had positive results. I felt relaxed, but not drugged. I was able to slip into sleep more easily, and I felt my anxiety was lessened. I was not groggy when I woke up, which I often am when I take other sleeping aids. I experienced no negative side effects, aside from its bitter taste. 

"Kratom is considered minimally toxic," notes a recent literature review in the International Journal of Legal Medicine (2015). "[W]ithdrawal symptoms are generally nonexistent to mild, even for heavy users." (http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00414-015-1279-y)

As Forbes explains, "An average of 110 [calls to poison centers]cases a year may sound like a lot, but it's not. It represents about 0.004 percent of the 3 million or so calls received by poison control centers each year. [...] The DEA not only fails to put the number of kratom-related calls in perspective; it does not mention that two-thirds of the cases were deemed 'minor' or 'moderate,' while only 7 percent (eight per year) were described as 'life-threatening.' " (http://www.forbes.com/sites/jacobsullum/2016/09/01/the-deas-crazy-kratom-ban-dresses-pharmacological-phobias-in-scientific-garb/#646b946c4f86)

I no longer have kratom in my tea, and I experienced no withdrawal symptoms. I have had addictions in the past to opiods and alcohol, and my experience with kratom was on par with a strong, peaceful nighttime tea. I purchased it legally, of course, online, and received a powered leaf suitable for tea. 

I also see this issue from the point of view of an Ohioan. The pain killer epidemic is a catastrophe. I am horrified at the number of overdoses we're seeing in Northeast Ohio. Banning kratom for everyone-- not just those under 18-- will fuel the overdose epidemic. The only beneficiaries are, perhaps, pharmaceutical companies. Public health will in no way benefit from banning kratom or listing it as a schedule I drug. I sympathize with the instinct to restrict supplements out of concern for addiction or harmful side effects. 

I did not experience any negative side effects from kratom. I stopped drinking kratom eventually just because it has, in my opinion, a bitter taste. Docket No. DEA-442W

Hello,

I am writing because kratom is my preferred method to start the day. I have tried both Coffee and Tea, however the caffeine causes me to get severe headaches and makes me feel jittery, and then caffeine withdrawal is even worse.

I have never had any negative side affects from kratom like I do from Coffee/tea, and have also never noticed any 'withdrawal' like effects.

I believe the DEA is severely overreaching in trying to schedule a coffee-like plant that is actually in the coffee family: a tropical evergreen tree in the coffee family, (source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mitragyna_speciosa ).

This plant should not be scheduled at all. Even restricting sales like alcohol or tobacco is unnecessary and would create unneeded regulation and bureaucracy that wouldn't help anyone.

DEA Cites 15 "kratom related" deaths, however I'll bet most if not all of those were caused by other factors: like a combination of drugs, and just happened to have kratom in their system, or other drugs + a very large amount of kratom, or something similar. In high quantities, I can imagine kratom can be dangerous, but the same is true of coffee/caffeine, sugar, alcohol, even water itself, etc. 

I am certain that far fewer poison control calls are made about kratom than from either cosmetics or household cleaners, and fewer emergency room visits about kratom than scissors. Data shows that the leading cause of adult poisonings is "analgesics," which include Tylenol, Vicodin, and other pain kills, but kratom is not included in this figure (source: http://www.poison.org/poison-statistics-national ) I have requested further data from aapcc.org to help emphasize these points, but wanted to be sure my comment was submitted before the cutoff date. I am sure that you have access to this data yourself and can verify.

A small minority of people are always going to injure themselves with whatever they have around, it's ridiculous to ban a useful coffee-like plant  because of a few fools. That line of thinking would require banning all household chemicals, alcohol, tobacco, firearms, hammers, and just about any other dietary supplement or tool you can think of.

While researching kratom for this comment, I learned that many people claim kratom can be used to help break dependence on opiate drugs, including Vicodin, Oxycodone, and Heroin. If you drink a cup of coffee and the next day drink a cup of kratom (if you don't drink either normally) you will feel much stronger effects from the coffee.

Let's please use common sense in this case and keep kratom unscheduled; as I said, coffee + tea make me unable to function due to caffeine induced headaches, and kratom helps start the morning without that jittery feeling of caffeine.

To Whom It May Concern,

I write to you as a concerned American citizen. Your proposal to ban kratom without any significant medical studies backing your claims is indicative of your organization's outlook as a whole; but it doesn't have to be. You have the power, starting with this tiny step, to reconsider your hardline position on the War on Drugs. When the people talk about a waste of taxpayer money, our private and public prison systems come to mind. Which you so happily stock like cattle over this failed attempt at control. 
I'm originally from a small town, Johnstown, PA. It used to be a thriving hub where America's steel was happily produced day in day out, but once the steel mill's left, so too did all of our hope and jobs. With that left all of the recreation opportunity. But still it clung on, relatively safe and happy. That is until a much more insidious type of drug dealer entered our town, the state-sanctioned one. Pill pushing doctors, fat on pharma-money overprescribed narcotic painkillers at an alarming rate. With the powderkeg of nothing-else-to-do in town, use skyrocketed. We went from a safe town to a kid I knew in high school being murdered a couple blocks from my childhood house two weeks ago. Once the doctor's stopped prescribing through legislation, large illegal drug operations found a perfectly intact framework through which to push their product. Now heroin is the norm. 
You may be thinking, "Shouldn't you be against this then??" No, for I've actually done research and considered the issue. Throughout the history of human kind, we have all been experimenting with different intoxicants in various ways. If prohibition of alcohol taught us anything, it is that you cannot legislate morality. Once it was illegal, vicious thugs and gangsters took over the alcohol trade. Use was not effected, but communities were. Innocent people fell victim, and we created more problems than we solved. There's not enough characters here to truly comment entirely how I feel, to cover every base. I know you guys know, and if you don't then I'm not confident that you should be entrusted with anything, let alone people's livelihoods. 
I know the effects illegal drugs can have on people, and kratom is not even in the same ballpark. It is an herb that helps people get through their days. As it stands it's relatively affordable and accessible for those who use it. It helps people get off of opiates, which is a near impossible task. It has never killed anyone on its own, no one breaks into shops to steal it, it's a plant. Stop outlawing nature.

The war on drugs not only costs this country a large amount of it's lower classes' youth, whether through the prison industrial complex, death from drug related accidents, or 

Underneath all of the bureaucracy and mal-intent, you guys are human just like all of us. Somewhere in there a small shred of empathy clings to life.


Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
I am a 27 -year old Landscaper and Classical Guitarist who has been using Kratom for 3 years to manage chronic pain and insomnia, but how I first came to Kratom was through management of opiate addiction.
I am a recovering heroin addict and had been clean for 7 years, when some unfortunate events in my life led me looking for a path back to heroin. When a friend encouraged me to try Kratom instead, I was skeptical but agreed; I can honestly say it may have saved my life. 
Had I not been introduced to Kratom, I would almost certainly have returned to a life of living from fix to fix. Instead, I actually became more productive, had more energy and coincidentally started sleeping again and living with less pain.
I have never had any type of 'overdose' from Kratom - taking more than I need simply isn't appealing (I find it analogous to drinking too much coffee (both are botanically classified as members of the Rubiaceae family) which I also don't find appealing), but when I was still experimenting to find an appropriate dosage, when I did take more than ideal, it was in no way debilitating, it just didn't improve my quality of life.
While I would like to believe that I have grown stronger as a person (spiritually, strong willed etc.), I do fear that if Kratom were no longer available, should I face another traumatic event in life I may fall into my old traps of addiction. 
I find the intention to schedule Kratom, especially as schedule 1, very difficult to understand, given its long history of use to treat opiate addiction and chronic pain.
Unfortunately, there are people who will abuse Kratom, that can't be denied. But to take an important medicine away from everyone because of a small number of irresponsible individuals seems entirely contrary to our existing policies on psychoactive substances. Alcohol, tobacco, even many of our over-the-counter medications like Robotussin and Cordicidin are abused by countless people, but we accept that the benefits they provide outweigh the unfortunate potential for exploitation and abuse. 
I accept that there may be long-term negative effects from habitual Kratom use, but so far we just don't have that information, and the absence of knowledge as a justification for criminalization is not congruent with our way of governing. To the best of my knowledge, all deaths associated with Kratom have involved other illicit substances as well and can not be attributed confidently to Kratom alone.
 People deserve the right to manage their pain and psychological weaknesses (i.e. addictions) with affordable (I have been spending about $80/month, compared to hundreds or thousands with illicit and prescription opiates) and natural options, should a person not want/be able to participate in the outrageously expensive world of prescription drugs; and for people in recovery like myself, being given prescription opiate pain killers for surgery etc as the only option is very likely to lead a person back into addiction.
 This country faces a growing opiate crisis and I strongly feel that at this point we should not be eliminating any promising treatment options.
I hope that very intentional and open-minded deliberation will be employed as the decision making process regarding the scheduling of Kratom continues to unfold. I thank you for taking the time to consider my experience.

documents.commentText:
RE: Docket No. DEA-442W - my comments


Hello, my name is David, I am 32 years old, a college graduate, and gainfully employed as a full stack web developer (LAMP stack). I am grateful you have opened up the commenting period for the considered scheduling of kratom. I would like to express my vehement opposition to any scheduling of kratom. 


I have been using this natural supplement for four years to contribute to my mental state and general well-being. I have suffered from recurrent major depressive disorder for most of my adult life. In my early twenties, I found myself in a grave and deepening depression and I sought formal treatment for the condition. Over the course of two years I was rotated through half a dozen different pharmaceuticals with no success. Provided you haven't experienced that, you could try and imagine the pain, anguish, and hopelessness you would feel... but you'd be wrong.


At this point, in the darkest of places I've ever found myself in, my family and physicians tried something desperate; they put me on suboxone. The use of opiates was at the time, and still is now, a fairly radical and experimental approach to treatment resistant depression. However, my situation was growing quite severe, so I was prescribed suboxone and monitored by a licensed physician. In all likelihood, the decision probably saved my life. I was at a point where something needed to change. 


However, suboxone doesn't really lend itself to great overall health, or a productive lifestyle, over the long term. The side effects are significant; extreme constipation, severe nausea, hypogonadism (I needed to self-administer testosterone injections), zero sex drive (probably because of the hypogonadism), and fatigue/excessive sleep. Additionally, since the treatment was so radical, insurance wouldn't cover the costs of the treatment, which was exorbitant. I used suboxone as a crutch to finish my degree, a BAS in Computer Technology, and then voluntarily quit taking it. The hope was that enough time had passed, that enough in my life had changed and I would no longer need it. But this is a condition I am stuck with, and I found myself still needing help every now and again. 


This is when I discovered kratom. It is a beautiful herbal supplement. I use kratom to elevate my mood when my depression gets the better of me. There is no cure for depression, but kratom helps me and contributes to my mental well-being. Despite some of what your notice of intent stated, kratom is remarkably safe. Studies, such as those done by Dr. Kruegel and Dr. Boyer, have evidenced that the risks of respiratory depression (the leading cause of death associated with opiate use) is not consistent with the effects of kratom. When I use kratom, it elevates my mood and provides a sense of well being without clouding my judgment or interfering with my cognitive abilities. The most significant side effect I have experienced, in four years' time, has been mild nausea.  


It is my sincerest hope that all of the comments you have received enlighten your perspective and correct your misconception. Kratom isn't a party drug. We aren't drug addicts teetering on the precipice of self-destruction. We don't need you to save us from ourselves. We are responsible men and women of all ages and walks of life. We are your neighbors and productive members of society. For different reasons, and in different circumstances, we found this wonderful and safe herb that helps us be those things; kratom contributes to our overall health and quality of life. You do not have the moral authority to deprive us of that.

To whom it may concern:
I have used Kratom for many years as a treatment for fibromyalgia. It ha allowed me to keep a full time job doing remain a productive member of society, rather than having to go on disability and become a public burden instead/ If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people like me will be criminalized and could be locked up behind bars. Our prisons are already bursting to the brim and the last thing we need is to increase the number of nonviolent prisoners, especially those just seeking relief from chronic pain or other conditions. We already imprison far too great a portion of our population, certainly relative to other civilized countries but even just objectively. 
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement. I have used Kratom for many years as a treatment for fibromyalgia. I have never experienced any negative effects, and the positive effects are far greater than any that prescription medications have provided - without any of the terrible side effects. For example, one of the drugs I was prescribed gave me serotonin syndrome, a life-threatening condition from which I narrowly escaped death. Now I cannot tolerate any substances that affect serotonin production and still, years later, am struggling with the effects of serotonin syndrome. 
The few so-called Kratom-related deaths all involve other, much more dangerous substances that are doubtless the true cause of death rather than Kratom. To suggest otherwise is simply disingenuous. 
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it. Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose. For instance, in Alabama, when Kratom was banned, they saw the number of opiate addictions and consequent deaths rise immediately. 
Compassion for those struggling with conditions that can be safely treated with Kratom use is what is called for in this situation. Regulation to control for quality would help ensure that users do not end up with contaminated substances. An all-out ban,treating Kratom as if it were as dangerous as heroin, will criminalize more non-violent people who simply want to alleviate conditions that prescription drugs don't work for, and sometimes produce sometimes life-threatening side-effects. Please act on the side of public safety and compassion, keeping Kratom legal. Thank you for your time and consideration.

My name is Chris and I am a OIF Army combat Veteran.

I was deployed over seas to Iraq in 2009 with the 137th AVN Battalion out of Columbus, OH.  I spent one year in Iraq and encountered incoming mortar fire on a daily basis.  When I returned home just before Christmas of 2009, I had a lower back injury (bulging disk) and could barely move without extreme sharp pain.

Over the course of 6 months I went through physical therapy at my local VA three times a week.  We did exercises to help strengthen my muscles around my lower back and learned stretching techniques to help deal with the pain.  After the 6 months of therapy I felt a lot better but was informed that the injury was permanent.  I would go a couple months without pain and then it will flare up and return for a month or two. 

To top off the back injury, shortly after returning home I started showing signs of PTSD.  I would have extreme anxiety attacks where I could feel my mortality and felt as if my heart could stop at any minute.  I was so terrified of death even the sight of a grave yard could trigger the attacks.  I also was over paranoid about anything and would find myself sleeping on the couch by the front door.  Having never owned a gun in my life, I purchased a AR-15 and about five other firearms because I felt insecure not having one by my side. 

As time went on I realized I had little interest in doing the things I loved before and I was constantly angry over the littlest things.  Driving anywhere or being in a crowded public place was damn near impossible without my blood starting to boil.  I would find myself lashing out at my wife and kids over things that were so petty.  I finally decided I needed help.

I went to the VA and starting discussing my issues with a counselor and psychiatrist in late 2010 and still see them on a monthly basis to this day.  We tried many different anti depressants, sleeping aids, group counseling, personal counseling, you name it and while it did help me a bit nothing really took care of it.  I decided to start doing some research to see if there was any other options.

In June of 2015, a friend of mine introduced me to Kratom.  I was told it helped him with his pain and also provided a mood lift.  I decided it couldn't hurt and that I would give it a shot.  I took my first dose on a empty stomach and with 30 minutes I could tell something was different.  I was calming down, started to feel happy, I felt ambitious to go do something, I actually started to feel normal.  To top it all off, while it didn't completely eliminate my back pain, it helped immensely!  I now had manageable pain instead of unbearable pain. 

For about 6 months I took it on a daily basis.  I had a lot more motivation, I was calm with my kids and enjoyed doing more with them, dealing with crowds was getting a bit better, I could sleep good, overall everything was going well.  I now no longer take Kratom everyday.  I use it here and there when my back pain returns or if I feel that I may be going into a stressful situation.  I am happy to have found such an amazing natural alternative to pharmaceutical medications.

Please reconsider your action to make kratom a scheduled substance.  This plant is very important to me and my family.

My name is Janie Rae. I have never drank, never smoked, never used illegal drugs. Ever. I was a mom, a Sunday School teacher, and a mentor to teen girls at risk. In 1995, I was hit by a drunk driver and was in critical condition for 19 days. I went through 13 surgeries on my spine, hips, legs, and knees. Afterwards, I was on pain meds, but I was still in constant pain. I could no longer drive, no longer teach, no longer mentor. I couldn't cook, clean, or take care of my four school-age children. Four years ago, after being on pain meds for 17 years, my doctor said she could no longer prescribe them and I'd have to go to a pain doctor. I went to my first visit. The waiting room was overflowing and dirty. Most of the people in the room looked pretty sketchy. I finally got to see the doctor. He had me raise my arms over my head (my pain is in my back, hips, and legs), and handed me a prescription. I felt dirty, like I was doing something illegal. 

I went back to my primary care doctor, and I cried as I told her how horrible my experience was at the pain clinic. She said she was sorry, but that was the only option now. She suggested I try to take a break from pain meds entirely. The thought of that scared me to death, as I hurt bad enough with them and I was always watching the clock to see when I could take my next dose. But I really didn't want to go back to the pain doc at the pain clinic. So, I agreed. My doctor warned me that since I'd been on pain meds for so long (vicodin and oxycodone), that I'd probably be sick for a few days. I was also in so much pain that I thought I might die from it. The sickness passed, but the pain didn't. I didn't know what to do. At my doctor's suggestion, I tried Lyrica and other arthritis meds, but they didn't help me. I tried anti-depressants, muscle relaxers, you name it. Nothing helped. I finally asked her to send another referral to the pain clinic. 

While I was waiting for my appointment date (it was almost three months away), I looked on Google for alternative treatments for pain. I found Kratom, and ordered some. Always the skeptic, I put it back for over a week. Then, one day, my pain was so unbearable, I pulled out the kratom, shoved some into vitamin capsules, and swallowed. Thirty minutes later, my pain was gone. I was amazed. Since then, I use it regularly when my pain is unbearable. Between usages, I have no cravings and no withdrawal. It truly is a miracle, I am able again to be a mom, take care of my family, and mentor  teens. 

Without kratom, I'd have to return to vicodin--and I'd have to go to that horrid pain clinic. Please keep kratom legal and available. It has so much improved my quality of life. Thank you. Janie Rae

documents.commentText:
Kratom is simply the leaves from a tree related to coffee, with effects that are somewhat similar. It's a mild-to-moderate stimulant. I've used it for years with no ill effects--I continue to run a successful small business and care for my children. It has only helped me to stay active, and ease my back pain, without me having to use prescription opiates.

Kratom is not unsafe--the DEA has linked Kratom to only 12 deaths (far fewer than from even caffeine or sugarcane), and in most of those cases, kratom had been combined with killer drugs like heroin. Simple logic tells us that this data is barely relevant or useful. 

The limited research we have suggests that kratom acts on opiate receptors in the brain--so does chocolate, cheese, and many other things. Some people have used higher doses of kratom to help them get off heroin or the similar, highly-addictive, prescription pain pills; the FDA also called this a "misuse" of kratom. Kratom isn't killing people like heroin, and--unlike heroin--kratom isn't responsible for criminality, and won't make anyone lose their job, friends, or family. If anything, this suggests that we have an opportunity to curb prescription and heroin abuse. (And if kratom is scheduled alongside heroin, anyone who tries kratom and sees how innocuous it is, might then wonder if the DEA is also lying about heroin's dangers. So its scheduling would delegitimize the government's stance on heroin.) 

Also, kratom isn't new--it has been used for literally thousands of years in Southeast Asia (and yet we've never heard of it, which alone points to how safe it is) and in many of those countries, it isn't considered a drug. In countries where it is considered a drug, it's compared to coffee, associated with working hard, and sometimes promoted as a better alternative to marijuana. How am I aware of all of this, yet the DEA isn't? Respectfully, but honestly, the DEA should be ashamed. To try to try to designate a plant Schedule I before even researching it or consulting scientists or the public? That should be criminal.

We spend at least $50 billion a year on the War on Drugs. Since it began in 1971, we've spent over $1.5 trillion. The addiction rate? Literally unchanged, 45 years and $1.5 trillion later. The War on Drugs stigmatizes those who abuse them, which deters them from getting treatment. documents.commentText:
I oppose the scheduling of kratom. At best, the argument against kratom is based on faulty, hasty science. I applaud the DEA's decision to seek input from the FDA before moving forward with this ban. 

Your standards claim that Schedule I is for substances "with no currently accepted medical use and a high potential for abuse." Kratom meets neither of these conditions. I will also address your third criterion, "lack of accepted safety for use under medical supervision", and some other justifications that I believe are illogical. 

Regarding medical use:

In the absence of a peer-reviewed study confirming kratom's health benefits, we must rely for now on anecdotal evidence, which overwhelmingly says that kratom is an effective treatment for chronic or post-surgical pain (and therefore a safe alternative to opiates), and that it can help opioid addicts eventually stop using drugs altogether. Please do not conflate "absence of evidence" with "evidence of absence".

Regarding potential for abuse: 

There has not yet been a large-scale study calculating the rate of side effects or addiction, so again, we must rely on the numbers available, which say that kratom is safe and not addictive. The DEA itself has claimed that millions of dosage units have entered the US, but that the drug has only been implicated in 15 deaths (in most of which, kratom's role was unconfirmed), an incredibly low rate. 

Regarding the lack of accepted safety for use under medical supervision:

Medical research has not yet caught up with this helpful drug, and therefore doctors haven't had a chance to develop usage guidelines. Furthermore, kratom research may be the key to safer pharmaceutical painkillers, but if the substance is scheduled, such research may never get off the ground, and the current trend of opiate prescriptions will be forced to continue.

Regarding your claim that, "the identity, purity, and quantity of these substances are uncertain and inconsistent, thus posing significant adverse health risks to users" (in your Proposed Rule document from August 31):

The most effective way to protect people from this problem is with FDA regulations. Scheduling kratom will only force it onto the black market, thus further exposing its users to additives, impurities, and other dangers.

Kratom does not meet the standards of a Schedule I substance. It is a safe recreational drug, and a potentially useful (but currently under-researched) medicine. Banning the substance will not make America safer. It will only serve to exacerbate America's opioid addiction problem, completely destroy the quality of life for many chronic pain sufferers, and create more health risks for kratom users.

Thank you for your consideration.

My name is Mallory Smith. I'm 30 years old, and my great passion is (thankfully) also my full-time job. I'm an event professional, coordinating the planning and execution of events ranging from small R&D strategy sessions to music festivals boasting more than 18,000 attendees. I grew up in a family that founded multiple bluegrass music festivals, and I'm so thankful that I was raised to love this labor of mine.

Unfortunately, my job and passion doesn't always come easy to me. I was diagnosed with spondylolisthesis when I was 19 years old. This is a birth defect of the spine, which results in one or more vertebrae sliding out of place, causing misalignment, poor balance, and chronic pain. At age 29, I was forced to have spinal fusion surgery (age 29!) to keep it from becoming worse. By the time of my operation, my L5 vertebrae had slipped more than 75% off of my S1 (sacral joint). There was no way to safely postpone the surgery. It could only be corrected to about 50%, so I still have a chronic pain and am now starting on month 11 of physical therapy. 

To cope with the pain, which was often so bad that I couldn't sleep, my doctor had no choice but to prescribe me numerous opiate painkillers, nerve medication, and muscle relaxers. All of them left me in a fog, and my job and family suffered for it. I have a 9 year old son who loves nothing more than to go hiking with me on weekend and I wasn't able to go more than a mile without being completely overcome with pain. And this was AFTER my surgery. At this point, I started getting very depressed about my situation. I mean, I was 30 years old and facing down a life of either chronic pain, or long-term vicodin use. Having grown up in eastern Kentucky, I had witnessed first-hand how destructive prescription painkillers were, and the thought of having to rely on them terrified me. I tried super high doses of tylenol, modified yoga, steam, electrotherapy, a new mattress, even new shoes. Nothing worked as well as the heavy-duty painkillers, and it just sucked. 

About three months ago, a friend recommended that I try kratom. I'd never heard of it, so I did some research and ordered a beginner's pack from a recommended online vendor. After the very first use, of which I only had to take about 1 tsp., I felt better than I had in years. My pain was nearly gone, but I didn't have the opiate fog. I had energy, I found myself able to walk farther and perform better in physical therapy, and my depression lifted. Even my anxiety, which had moderately plagued me since my teenage years to the point where I had trouble being the passenger in a vehicle without a mild panic attack, became a non-issue. I honestly have never felt better than I have over these past few months, and I wasn't "high". I wasn't in pain, and I was happy. But when I heard that the DEA was planning to ban it, making it a Scheule 1 no less, I was shocked and heartbroken.

I was a teenager once. I tried a wide variety of party drugs, drank beer, and got into all of the usual trouble a teen does. At most, it is the world's greatest cup of coffee, sprinkled with a safe painkiller that doesn't get you hooked. In light of today's opiod epidemic, how on earth could something that safely replaces such a dangerous family of drugs be deemed as a health hazard with no medical benefits? I won't repeat all of the statistics that show how many people have died from opiate overdoses vs kratom. But I will tell you this: banning kratom will absolutely do more harm than good. Banning it is simply unsafe, and irresponsible. Even my surgeon, who didn't know anything about it until I told him a month after I started using it, now sings its praises and advises most of his patients to use it in place of traditional opiates. 

This stuff has gave me my life back, and I'm not even one of the most extreme cases. I've heard testimonials from disabled veterans, accident survivors, even those born with crippling deformities talk about how much it has helped them. Banning it will make criminals out of millions of people who have finally found safe, non-addictive relief. 

Please, I urge you to reconsider this. Let universities and labs continue studying kratom, because they continue to find how helpful it is, and it could very well save the lives of hundreds of thousands of opiate addicts. Our country is being crippled by these new surges in heroin addiction, and there's an alternative that won't kill people. How on earth does it make sense to ban the one thing that might be able to save us?

I don't want to go back to painkillers. I don't want to go back to sleepless nights and being unable to stand. 

I'm 30 years old. I want to enjoy the rest of my life without pain or pills. My son doesn't want to lose his hiking partner again, and he wants his whole "Mom". Please don't make me a criminal.

documents.commentText:
In general at this time in history, we're moving towards destigmatizing drug use (not to be confused with ABuse). Scheduling Kratom would be a move in the wrong direction - it would expand and perpetuate the failed "War on Drugs", and remove folks' rights for a victimless act. From a purely logistical standpoint, we already have an overwhelming percent of our populace with their freedom taken away - our prison system cannot continue growing. 

On the whole, the United States of America is based on the belief that the public are their own rulers - that is, we are not supposed to have a ruling class telling the masses what to do, believe, and think. This should expand to drug policy, where an overwhelming majority support an end to Richard Nixon's racist "War on Drugs". The United States' federal government has an obligation to listen to its populace's needs and desires, and try its best to act accordingly. Sometimes, this means admitting that programs were wrong in the first place and must be ended. Sometimes this means admitting we were wrong.

Practically, millions of people in the United States already safely use Kratom for a pain reliever and to detox themselves from powerful opioids. If we were added to Schedule I, we would be removing those peoples' choice to care for their own health as they choose. Moreover, it would remove all opportunity to study the drug and scientifically vet its medicinal possibilities and study its affects.

I urge the DEA to not schedule Kratom, on the basis that doing so would perpetuate our priston crisis, remove peoples' freedoms for (what would be) a victimless crime, go against the will of the public, and remove peoples' ability to care for their own health as they choose.

documents.commentText:
This comment in reference to Docket No. DEA-442W

To whom it may concern,

The DEA has a responsibility to the taxpaying citizens of the United States of America to recognize the medical properties of Kratom, despite the lack of supporting medical research. 

In its own announcement of intent to schedule Kratom, the DEA states "Kratom is abused for its ability to produce opioid-like effects..." This alone, never mind the lists of accounts from people who are able to safely use Kratom, indicates that Kratom possesses medicinal uses as a maintenance therapy for or to aid in the detoxification of people with opioid dependence.

The literature that the DEA cites regarding the intented scheduling of Kratom in the US recognized that of the 663 calls made to US Poison centers related to Kratom exposure, more than 35% of those involved multiple exposures including ethanol, other botanicals, benzodiazepines, narcotics, and acetaminophen. 

All of the side effects and risks associated with kratom, as noted by the CDC and as cited by the DEA, are very similar to innumerable over the counter, or DEA schedule III drugs. Additionally, the one death noted in the CDC literature admits that the person was also exposed to Paroxetine, an antidepressant and Lamotrigine, an anticonvulsant/mood stabilizer. It does not mention what the death was due to. 

In its intent, the DEA states "Because the identity, purity levels, and quantity of these substances are uncertain and inconsistent, they pose significant adverse health risks to users." This may be true, but it is not sufficient to classify Kratom as a schedule I drug.

In its intent, the DEA states it "is aware of 15 kratom-related deaths between 2014 and 2016." That is approximately 7.5 deaths per year in which Kratom exposure was present but not necessarily the cause of death. This is in contrast to the tens of thousands of people who die every year in the US alone due to unintentional overdose of non-opioid prescription and over the counter medications, all FDA approved as cited by the CDC.

The allegations being made about Kratom by the DEA are dramatic, untrue, and incomprehensible. If the DEA really has its motives and interests in helping the people of the USA, it will not proceed with its decision to schedule Kratom as class I, as people across the country are using it safely and responsibly for its true medicinal uses.

I am requesting that the DEA reconsider classifying Kratom as a different Schedule or reconsider its scheduling altogether.

Thank you for your time in reading this.

PLEASE don't  take away Kratom. This substance is literally saving lives.

To Whom it May Concern,

I am a certified K-12 teacher. I have two MA degrees, no criminal record at all, and I currently work as a teacher trainer preparing our future educators. I have been working in education for nearly 30 years. I am a normal middle-aged person with chronic pain stemming from sports injuries I suffered in my youth.

I mention this to emphasize my commitment to public service and the public good. Public service is my life. I was on the brink of losing my ability to work due to chronic pain and that disturbed me so much that I noticed that, at the age of 55, I was starting to experience signs of depression, and that scared me.

Doctors had been prescribing strong NSAIDs for me for the last twenty years. I cannot take them any longer. Before I found kratom, I used a dosage of diclofenac suggested by a doctor that caused debilitating side effects. NSAIDs do cause internal bleeding, stroke, and heart disease, this is a fact (1). The men in my family all die of heart disease. I do not need any help in that area.

So I lived with the pain, often unable to sit long enough to grade a simple paper, unable to attend meetings, and growing increasingly concerned for my family's well being. 

Then I found kratom. I cannot tell you how much it has helped my life. Truly, it has changed everything. It allows me to work. It does not get me 'high'; on the contrary, experiencing less pain, depression, and anxiety, it allows me to focus, work, and enjoy my day. 

I have been using kratom for about 1 year and have experienced no negative side effects. It is not addictive for me and I find it to be safe and effective. I am a responsible, law-abiding citizen and I resent attempts to ban this supplement. And I vote. I vote every chance I get. 

To limit access to this truly helpful dietary supplement would be a disaster. It would be a destructive, uninformed, bone-headed move, and people will suffer if you ban kratom. 

Please, please take a balanced, informed view of this. Serve the public well.(2)

Footnote 1: No citation required. Simply read the label of any bottle of Ibuprofen or other NSAID.

I believe Kratom should remain legal.  I have only had incidence to use Kratom on 3 previous occasions, all to help manage anxiety, which it did so well.  I currently manage my anxiety with Effexor 75 mg three times daily, which helps but does not always address symptoms of panic / panic attacks. I am unaware of any lethal events or event significantly adverse health effects having occurred due to Kratom.  I believe, in the spirit of autonomy and independence that our country was founded upon, the lack of controlled, double blind / placebo studies demonstrating the clear efficacy of a substance should not be substantial enough to permit anyone or any agency to determine that it is of no medical value.  I believe if that is to be the conclusion then that burden should fall to the body or agency seeking to ban it's access, and I think those results should have to be very conclusive towards that determination.  I think that this alone will preclude any further serious consideration of banning or otherwise scheduling Kratom, but at the least a process like this would legitimize the position that there is inherent danger in Kratom, a claim that, absent of such evidence, will appear to be and likely will be unsubstantiable scientifically if not also transparently driven by secondary interests. 

Thank you for your time

documents.commentText: I'm extremely heartened to hear that the DEA is open to discussing the scheduling of kratoum. With the recent legalization of cannabis in several more states, it seems that the tide of public opinion is turning, and it's good that there are forward-thinking people in the DEA who can recognize this. I'm asking that the DEA withdraw its proposed action of making kratoum a Schedule 1 substance. I hope that instead it can be regulated by the BATF in the same manner as alcohol, and also regulated as a herbal supplement by the FDA, in order to ensure the safety of consumers. Yes, kratoum can be mildly addictive and can be used for recreation, but so can many prescription drugs. Its side effects and addictive potential are far less than pharmaceutical painkillers, or our society's favorite recreational drug: alcohol. I don't use kratoum, I tried it and it caused a very bad nausea reaction in me--but I know that it greatly benefits others, especially those who are trying to quit opiates or who suffer from chronic pain. Each individual ultimately has the final say on what they want to put in their body, and should be informed of the consequences. I tried kratoum and got nausea from it, but that doesn't mean I want to stop others from using it if they benefit from it. I think every family in the US has been touched by the current epidemic of heroin and prescription painkiller addiction. Mine has been. Kratoum is a safe and cheap medicine that can help those people quit pills and heroin. Rehab can cost thousands of dollars, and in many cases, it is a for-profit business that operates on outdated treatment principles. I know one person who became addicted to pain pills from a doctor, and when those ran out he turned to heroin. His family paid for rehab but it didn't work. The only thing that worked for him was doing an at-home detox. With his family there to help him, he made it through some very difficult days of withdrawl and is now drug-free and in NA. That is exactly the kind of person that kratoum could help. I kept kratoum in my family medicine cabinet, in case of severe pain or injury. (I'm unable to afford health insurance, so a doctor's visit could mean thousands of dollars in medical bills.) With all the problems in our health care system, I think people should be allowed to use any treatment they see fit for themselves and their families, even if some people disagree with their choices. As for the economic impact of the proposed scheduling, I think that making this plant an illegal product would greatly benefit drug cartels and the pharmaceutical industry which is flooding our society with dangerous and addictive synthetic painkillers. Also, making it Schedule 1 would create difficulties in doing scientific research on it in the future. Ultimately, kratoum is a plant, not a crime. It's legal almost everywhere in the world---and the rest of the world follows the US in regard to drug policy. So please, let's keep this interesting and useful plant available on the market, and allow consumers to make their own informed decisions about whether or not to use it.

I am a 33-year-old male. Kratom saved my life. I have now been using Kratom daily, like coffee, for 10 years. I just had a blood test done at my local convenient care and it came back 100% normal AS I EXPECTED. Kratom is simply a mild, harmless stimulant like coffee.

I have struggled with treatment-resistant depression since I was 10 years old. Throughout high school and college I considered suicide many times, self-mutilated, and tried just whatever drugs I could get a hold of. Acid, shrooms, pot. 12 years ago I was put on suicide watch at my college. I was told I just "looked" like a danger to myself. I worked my way through therapy, pills, the whole bit. None of it helped. 

A real wake-up call happened that year. A friend gave me some Prozac and suggested it helped him.  He neglected to mention that Prozac and alcohol don't mix. That night I nearly killed myself, and woke up the next day in a full bathtub with a butcher knife on the floor. I had no idea what happened, and suspect I'm only alive because I passed out before killing myself.

2 years later I realized I was a full-blown alcoholic. I was managing to hold on to a well paying job with the degree I'd earned, but just barely. The depression was suffocating. The alcohol was no longer fun: my soul felt eroded. I felt dead inside. 

As I hit rock-bottom, desperate, I joined a message board for people with chronic pain and depression, looking for any suggestions I hadn't tried. Someone told me to talk to a woman suffering from Mulitiple Sclerosis who'd had great success with an herb called Kratom. She turned out to be the first person I bought Kratom from: a chronic pain sufferer who found relief nowhere else. These are the adults you seek to harm by banning Kratom: real people who have found a safe alternative to DANGEROUS prescription medication which the DEA apparently sees as less of a problem than a harmless herbal alternative. 

When Kratom first arrived I tried it a few times but it basically sat in the cupboard because I actually couldn't tell if it was DOING anything. This is what you compare to heroin and crack? I passed it up for a bottle of Jim Beam because it was a BETTER HIGH. Seriously, I got a better "high" from coffee. Months later, in a pit, i tried Kratom again because people online kept insisting it helped, and I started to notice some things: I felt like I could breath again, stronger, more interested in my work, excited about life again.

Over the next few months I weaned myself off of alcohol, and I slowly learned to smile again. Now, I haven't drank or used ANY illegal drug in almost 10 years. Instead, I've learned to depend on the gentle stimulation, and the anti-depressive effects Kratom has for me personally.

Please, consider other people's lives. I am happy and well adjusted now. I'm not hurting anyone else, and I'm not hurting myself as I proved through the blood test. A broad total ban to stop a few kids from getting ahold of it is not the solution. Banning Kratom hurts real people. The risk is negligible next to the real drug threats we face: prescription drug abuse, an opiate epidemic (which Kratom is helping to fight), alcoholism, tobacco deaths. Let's get our priorities straight instead of demonizing innocent people. 

I love my wife, I love my nephews, and I love my job. I am living the American Dream, and my life is better than I ever imagined it could be. I am a mild to moderate daily user. I am happy and well-adjusted. You want to take this away from me. Why? Why can't we show the world for once that America can be reasonable, thoughtful, and moderate. Thanks for your time.

documents.commentText:
I am writing to request that kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) and its components(mitragynine, 7-hydroxymitragynine) NOT be placed, temporarily nor permanently, into Schedule 1.
Kratom is not an immanent hazard or immediate threat to public safety.  Legal substances such as acetaminophen cause many more deaths per year in our country.  Acetaminophen deaths are calculated (by CDC and FDA) to be between 300 and 980 individuals per year (Gerth and Miller, 2013).  Kratom was found to be associated with 15 deaths in two years (DEA, 2016).  I believe kratom was not implicated as the lone cause in all cases.
Kratom does not have a substantial potential for abuse.  I have never seen a case of kratom abuse in my community.  A search of medical literature using PubMed does not reveal an epidemic of abuse nor extreme cases of dependency.  One article describing kratom abuse states that the withdrawal was "short and benign" (McWhirter and Morris, 2010).  Scientific research also describes the therapeutic potential of compounds in this herb (Hassan et al., 2013).  
As kratom is an herb not a drug, it does not require a currently accepted medical use nor an accepted safety for use under medical supervision.  It is correct kratom be categorized as an herb.
The main effects of scheduling kratom would be hardship for citizens who use it and for businesses that provide jobs and tax revenue.  Scheduling would also prevent further research into kratom's medical benefits and potential. 

Works Cited
DEA Public Affairs. (2016). DEA announces intent to schedule kratom. https://www.dea.gov/divisions/hq/2016/hq083016.shtml

Gerth, J. and Miller, T.C. (2013). Behind the numbers. https://www.propublica.org/article/tylenol-mcneil-fda-behind-the-numbers

Hassan, Z. et al. (2013). From Kratom to mitragynine and its derivatives: physiological and behavioural effects related to use, abuse, and addiction. Neurosci Biobehav Rev. 37(2), 138-51. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23206666

McWhirter, L., and Morris, S. (2010). A case report of inpatient detoxification after kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) dependence. Eur Addict Res. 16(4), 229-31. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20798544

To the DEA,

I am speaking as someone who takes a keen interest in public health, and is employed as a packer and warehouse manager by a business that sells kratom for research purposes. Therefore, not only the future health outcomes for Americans, but my job and my well-being are threatened by the prospect of your decision.

Given that I live in a country which shares the United States' over-prescription of legal opioid painkillers, and that these intense drugs are both legal and well-researched, I find the proposed scheduling, and thus the effective banning of the kratom without any comparable body of scientific research or evidence of harm to be obscene, hypocriticial, ridiculous and depressing. You invite ridicule, if not anger for your incompetence.

Individuals in the United States and the western world are being confronted by two acute problems: the opioid crisis (driven by high unemployment and the lack of safe, legal and low-intensity opioid and opioid-like substances) and better options for the treatment of chronic pain (which 10-50% of all people suffer from some form thereof).

It seems to me that banning kratom, without sufficient research, or sufficient evidence of danger compared to the various pharmaceutical and recreational drugs we already use legally to reduce pain (i.e. prescription painkillers and alcohol) will be immensely harmful, counterproductive and wasteful on both the above fronts. Additionally, you will likely drive underground the importation and distribution of kratom, both marginalizing and oppressing those who find it a suitable means of pain relief or recreation, and wasting taxpayer money on the confiscation of the substance and incarceration of those involved in the economy. This destroys the possibility of legal, well-paying businesses that distribute kratom like the one I work for existing in your country, and a ridiculous war on psychoactive substances that are tamer than alcohol.

I would strongly encourage you not to schedule the active ingredients of kratom, and thus to save yourself a world of crime, wasted money, and actual, literal pain.

Sincerely,
Martin Law

By 16 I was physiologically addicted to steadily increasing doses of methadone and had tried just about every pharmaceutical opioid prescribed in North America. During my 17th year of life I was using 800mg/day of Oxycontin (400mg 2x/day in the form of crushed and parachuted Oxycontin 80s) or 200-250mg/day of methadone. I ran a lucrative online business that allowed me to fund such a large habit. The oxycontin alone cost me at least $500 a day. 

Shortly after I turned 18, after almost 3 years of constant opioid (ab)use, my family packed up and moved back to my home state of Pennsylvania. I ended up living in a shoddy Florida Best Western hotel room for a few weeks, spending days in an agonizing cold-turkey 250mg/day methadone withdrawal due to the impact that the sudden collapse of the stock market had on my business. Most definitely one of the worst periods of my life. Under pressure from my family I took a Greyhound bus to Pennsylvania and moved in with my father. I arrived there with 20 ten mg methadone pills in my pocket, no cash to my name, no connections, and an incomprehensible 200mg+/day methadone habit to support. The methadone I had lasted me two days. 

After a week of agony, spirit crushing insomnia and depression, I broke. Dressed in all black and sporting a pair of women's sunglasses, I rode a bicycle to a pharmacy with the intention of holding it up. I had a note that said 'i have a gun. give me all the oxycontin, morphine, methadone, and dilaudid and nobody gets hurt.' Luckily for me a wheelchair bound elderly woman was blocking my access to the pharmacy counter. I was approached by the store manager and told to leave after 10 minutes of conspicuously staking out the pharmacy area while waiting for the old woman to leave. Discouraged and on the verge of suicide, I bicycled my way back home. 

I frantically searched the internet for something that would end this madness. In a moment of elucidation, I remembered reading about things like ibogaine that could help people cure addictions, but the DEA has banned that without complete research.  So I stumbled upon an herb called 'kratom' that was being studied for its potential as an alternative to methadone for people addicted to opioids. I quickly found an online vendor who sold kratom extract and promptly made an order. 

The kratom arrived the next day. I hastily tore apart the cardboard envelope like a small child would the wrapping on a Christmas present. I measured out 3 times the 'normal' dose, dumped the rancid tea smelling powder into a cup of water, stirred, and chugged. The mixture was very bitter and coarse, what one might expect drinking a mixture of sawdust and water to taste and feel like. After rinsing out my mouth I sat at a chair with my head down and waited. Within 30 minutes I felt 100 percent better. Such an overwhelming relief and serenity. I wasn't high but I was no longer desperately ill. Immediately I head upstairs to my room and took a long much needed nap. I awoke feeling like a new person. An answer to all my problems, this brown powder. 

Shortly thereafter I was ordering new shipments of kratom extract every few days. The kratom never gave me an opiate high. It gave me back my ability to sleep and function. documents.commentText:
My name is Daniel VanDeKerkhove. 
I am a Federal Law Enforcement Officer (U.S. Customs and Border Protection). 
I also serve as an elected Trustee for the local municipality in which I live. 
I am married and am the proud father of a 2-year old son, with another on the way. 
I have never used, nor have any interest in the personal use of nor distribution of Kratom.

Nevertheless...

I urge you to *NOT* add Kratom to the list of Schedule I Drug.

Placing Kratom on the list of Schedule I Drugs would be an enormous disservice to the American People, and would go against all rational analysis of the myriad of facts, stats, and patient testimonials that clearly show just how harmless [and yet positively life-changing] this herb truly is to so many of our citizens.  

Kratom has been used for thousands of years to treat a multitude of different illnesses, ailments, and conditions including: Chronic Pain, Depression, Anxiety, Opiate Dependence, Fatigue, Stress, and even Diabetes. 
It's reported by patients, doctors, and researchers alike to be More Effective and come with Far Less-Plentiful And Less-Severe Side Effects than many much more costly prescription drugs, and is virtually non-addictive...(*which is why the pharmaceutical companies are pushing hard to ban it, plain and simple*). 

Please cut through the hype that lobbyists are trying to sell to you - think logically about the side effects which they are blowing out of proportion, and see that they are the Exact Same Side Effects that people get from COFFEE (agitated temper, achy muscles, listlessness, tremors. Sound familiar?)... Interesting to note that Kratom and coffee plants are actually in the same [Rubiaceae] family within the plant kingdom.
The only "kratom-related" deaths (less than 20, in a 2-year span) were actually instances in which *Other Dangerous Illegal Substances* [such as cocaine] were also present...a genuinely dishonest stretch to imply that kratom was anything more than a side-note in those cases!

Through personal relationships I have made in my [small-town] community, I can personally attest to the accounts of two upstanding citizens I know who use Kratom when-needed to treat chronic pain, stress, and anxiety. They credit it with turning their lives around in ways prescription drugs never could, with none of the side effects. 
The one I know most closely is a well-respected father-of-two who is an active and cherished member in the community, who is recently recovering from a long-fought battle with cancer. He was In Tears when he heard that the DEA was going to schedule Kratom. He truly doesn't know what he'll do to treat his pain if the DEA bans it; he's tried everything else - and spent far more money doing so - with no success! Taking away kratom would literally turn his and his-family's lives upside down, all over again.

Categorizing Kratom as a Schedule I Drug would be on-par with the absurdity of likewise placing cannabis on that same list. As you're aware, 28 states [and our capital city of Washington D.C.] have legalized cannabis. This means that a majority of the states in our Union have now recognized the legitimacy of medicinal cannabis, and/or have gone farther in recognizing that the herb is indeed harmless enough that its recreational use should be protected by law. Millions of Americans agree - from doctors to plumbers, teachers to celebrities - cannabis saves lives, and improves the lives of many more. 
And So Does Kratom. 

But now the DEA - pushed by Big-Monied Pharmaceutical Companies who cannot patent and thus lock-in profits on this natural herb - is considering the placement of Kratom on the same list of Schedule I Drugs as cannabis. The American People and the great States of This Union have already rejected the DEA's demonization of cannabis, and are firmly aware of the agenda now pushing for the same erroneous labeling of Kratom. 

Such an act would be a shock to the conscious of Americans everywhere, and would lead to an outrage and distrust of the DEA by the American People; it truly would undermine the very efforts of law enforcement who work day and night to  remove *Actual* dangerous drugs from our streets, as their authority would be viewed as illegitimate, and they would be seen as nothing more than henchmen of Big Pharma [...further crippling public relations between law enforcement and the public who they serve]. 
Please don't create that sort of environment for our Police.

Classifying Kratom as a Schedule I drug would be a giant step backwards for the health and wellness of the citizens of this Great Nation, and would immeasurably hinder legitimate law enforcement efforts everywhere. Please do not let big-monied interests block access to this affordable and legitimate health supplement that millions of Americans rely on. 

Thank You,
Daniel VanDeKerkhove

RE: Docket No. DEA-442W - my comments

To whom it may concern,

I am a 29 year old emergency medical healthcare professional, and when patients come to see me it is usually the worst day of their life.  I deal with very sick people, but I also deal with the many drug seekers who utilize emergency services to obtain their drug of choice, and others who come to see me when they have overdosed.  I see patients every week who are addicted to drugs, and even more patients who come in due to acute and chronic alcohol related conditions.  What I am not seeing is anyone coming to the emergency department because of Kratom.  

Emergency scheduling of a substance is used when a substance is an immediate threat to public health and public safety; therefore, I cannot recommend that Kratom be placed into schedule one, because I do not feel that Kratom is a threat to public health or public safety.  Placing Kratom into schedule one will close the door on research, and may mean that Kratom stays locked into schedule one forever.  There are some pretty big claims being thrown around by the Kratom community that the plant can help with a laundry list of ailments including pain, anxiety, and even opioid withdrawal/addiction.  The only way these claims can be validated or disproved is by the scientific community preforming research on the plant, and this cannot happen when the plant is schedule one.  More research such as the article that just came out in The Journal of the American Osteopathic Association needs to be done. (Link to article is here: http://jaoa.org/article.aspx?articleid=2588524)

To summarize, I do not feel like Kratom is an immediate threat to public health or safety.  I am against placing Kratom into schedule one status.  I would like more research to be done on Kratom to help assess how the plant can be used, and what the benefits and risks of using the plant are.  I do feel that Kratom could benefit from being regulated as an herbal supplement until more research is conducted due to the fact that Kratom seems to be relatively benign when compared to alcohol, or even other substances that are on the market.

Regards,

Veteran
Military Emergency Healthcare
Nursing Student
